Even without the extreme heat, simply circulating the air in the rooms would seem to be expected. After sweating through the first night of our stay, we decided that we would check out. I offered to switch rooms to any bay-side room, regardless of the room being more or less expensive. They were not willing or able to accomodate us. They did say the bay-side rooms are booked for one to two years in advance - information that would have been helpful when I had booked four months earlier and made my request. We checked out and paid for our one night. The Sylvia is an old hotel, so I wasn't expecting it to look like a trendy new resort, but I was surprised that rooms looked like a bargain-priced hotel - more resembling an aging 1970s hotel instead of a classic 1911 apartment complex, which is what it was built as.. If you are considering staying, getting a room on the bay side should make for a very nice stay. It was at least 20-degrees cooler and gets a regular breeze. They also have great views and the hotel is in a very nice location next to Stanley Park. Also, the prices are the same for the bay-vew rooms as for the side of the hotel facing other buildings.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Sylvia”
Reviews.Author: jstowe
Reviews.Content: What a lovely hotel! Not cheap, but fantastic location with parking and close to public transport and right next to the bay. The hotel is quite art-deco and is not sumptuous or splendid, but is cute, with large clean rooms and all the immediate amenities you need. The staff are very helpful and friendly. Our luggage did not turn up at the airport and the Sylvia staff were very concerned and helpful in persuading shabby Air Canada to find it and send it to us. We would definitely recommend this hotel. Try and book a year in advance to get a sea view!

Reviews.Title: “Very happy”
Reviews.Author: GrahamWM
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Sylvia for a total of five nights at the start and end of our month-long trip around western Canada in May-June 2006. I’d read a mixed bag of reviews on Trip Advisor, but we were happy with what we got. It’s not brand new, but it’s perfectly adequate, in an excellent location (views, restaurants, access to Stanley Park and beach), for a relatively low price ($99 a night for a queen bed room), clean with friendly service, thick curtains (important when you’re jet lagged), free internet access, and nice classical music in the lobby, which looked lovely as the afternoon sun filtered through the Virginia creeper over the windows. The check-out was late (noon), and they looked after our luggage if we arrived early or left late. Hard to think of negatives, but the best we could do was that it was a struggle to maintain a constant shower temperature, there were no tea-making facilities in our room (some dearer rooms might have these), and with no air con or fan, it would probably get hot midsummer. There were new window sashes so we didn’t experience the problem mentioned on this site of having to prop windows open. None of the shortcomings were of great enough magnitude to lower our opinion of the place: recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Surprise”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Date: July 5th 2006 We have just returned from a trip to Canada ending with a 3 night stay in Vancouver. My husband and I arrived in town without a hotel reservation and so got to see most of the hotels around downtown. We checked the rooms of all the hotels that weren't full and frankly were disappointed with what we saw. We decided to have a waterfront lunch to cheer us up before reluctantly returning to book an overpriced $200/night room in a hotel where the room, the location and staff were all unappealing. We drove to the water and found a parking space which happened to be in front of an entrance to a small hotel. It turned out to be the Sylvia Hotel, a designated " Heritage Building" dating back to 1912. To our great relief they had a room available. The room we got seemed fairly new with a king sized bed overlooking a quiet tree lined side street. Not only was it one of the nicest rooms we saw, it was also the cheapest room at $159/night. Though the room had no air conditioning, and during our stay there was record breaking heat, the sea breeze always kept the room at a comfortable temperature. The location was fantastic. The hotel is in the area known as the west end . It is where the locals live and is full of small cafes, restaurants and stores. You just have to cross the road in front of the hotel to reach the beach of English Bay which is one of the entry points to Vancouver's Stanley Park. The hotel has an outdoor patio where you can eat or just sit with a coffee and enjoy the sunset over the ocean. The hotel is not modern, sleek or luxurious. The keys to the rooms are just that - keys. You lock your room and give them to the front desk, where friendly hotel personnel quickly learn your name and you become one of the hotel "family". Their advice for dining and places to see were spot on. The furniture in the lobby has seen better days, but the friendly atmosphere combined with the location and the price is one of Vancouver's best kept secrets. It turns out that the Sylvia Hotel has guests who have been coming to the hotel for years and this we found out while sitting in the lobby (where there is free wifi) and hearing comments by the other guests. Guests at the hotel ranged from young couples, families with children to empty nesters and retirees. We felt ourselves lucky to have found the Sylvia Hotel and enjoyed every minute we were there. If we visit Vancouver again we will definitely stay there. R. K from New Jersey

Reviews.Title: “not a good idea”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: They lost our online reservations, & of course I didn't have my confirmation #......But they did have rooms & put us in one with a king sized bed for $159 per night....which was $60 more than my reservation quote. Another woman was checking out at the same time as we were, & had the same problem of being quoted their lowest $99 rate, & then having to pay the $159 plus 15 in tax. I would not stay there again...yes a quiet neighborhood, but just an old hotel, not charming at all. I had the feeling they routinely do this to guests, as no apology or attempt at accommodation was made by the desk clerk.

Reviews.Title: “like a sweet University dorm room, worth staying at!”
Reviews.Author: bukkles
Reviews.Content: We decided to spend one more night in Vancouver as we hated to leave it behind...We had been staying at te Fairmont waterfront center Gold level so were pampered right out! The Fairmont also allows dogs in all rooms as a past reviewer complained that the Sylvia allowed dogs in ALL ROOMS!!! Anyhow, my husband, my dog and I stayed at the sylvia and the room was much like a clean Canadian University dorm room. We were happy to have a kitchen and the view was killer right onto the beach. We commented we could make the room into a great apt if we owned it. The hotel is fine, and I have pretty highs standards compared to most, it is just old thats all. It is worth a stay and on a sunny day which we had the neighborhood just brims with activity and energy. Check her out if you like fun...

Reviews.Title: “perfect location, charming hotel”
Reviews.Author: drummerliz
Reviews.Content: I loved the Sylvia. The Four Seasons she ain't and the old girl shows her age, but her charm is evident. The service is very good, everyone is cheerful and accomodating. The location is fantastic-beautiful views, stanley park, sea wall. Denman street has great coffee shops and restaurants. Vera's burger shack rocks. I highly recommend the Sylvia Hotel for budget travelers and those for whom location and charm are more important than opulence.

Reviews.Title: “Charming, historic hotel in GREAT location”
Reviews.Author: banff
Reviews.Content: Ready to leave your car in the parking lot and REALLY enjoy Vancouver? The Sylvia is the place! English Bay beach is outside the front door, dozens of great restaurants and shops are within a kilometre, and the whole Stanley Park seawall walk is moments away for you keen hikers. Our family of four had a top floor room with 10-foot ceilings and SIX windows facing in two directions, 2 queen beds, a single, and a double pullout -- for $120 Cdn per night! I couldn't believe the price. The surprise continued at breakfast, which was in a charming room facing the bay, good quality and very inexpensive. The building IS a little run-down, but the sheets are soft and clean, the beds are comfortable, the staff is pleasant and helpful. My one great fear is that someone will redevelop this charmer into something I can't afford!

Reviews.Title: “The BEST for us and our dog”
Reviews.Author: IfPenguinsCouldFly
Reviews.Content: Pets are welcome!! Gorgeous on-the-waterfront English Bay location. Very quiet residential neighborhood surroundings. The famous Stanley Park is within walking distance. Watch sunsets from their pub and enjoy an unimpeded view of English Bay. Or, cross the quiet street from the hotel entrance and take your dog for a walk along the paved walkways of the clean, manicured English Bay beach park (no dogs allowed on the sandy part of the beach where people swim). Rooms are charming, old-world, homelike comfortable...nothing luxurious or fancy-glitzy. Has a nice English Club atmosphere. Very clean. Exceptionally helpful and friendly staff. Walk to Stanley Park and to a huge selection of restaurants serving practically any ethnic cuisine you want. Parking attendant and parking on premises makes it easy for those travelling by car. They have a website with photos. Recommend making reservation waaaay ahead of time. The Sylvia Hotel used to be a best kept secret, but people like me keep raving about it and it is becoming very well known. Prices are very good for low-middle to high-budget travellers. I will always stay at The Sylvia Hotel whenever I am in Vancouver.

Reviews.Title: “Not heritage - just plain worn out”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I have to say that I found this place overwhelmingly disapointing. It is not historic and charming - just old and worn out. Rooms were cold and dimly lit,and the desk did nothing to alleviate the problem. In fact the woman "in charge" was quite hostile. The hotels saving grace was the location. Stunning, though not worth a second stay.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: CatsWhiskars
Reviews.Content: Great location next to the beach and Stanley Park. Room was on the small side but clean and pleasant enough.

Reviews.Title: “Wanted to love it....”
Reviews.Author: Broken_Foot_Mama
Reviews.Content: ...but just couldn't. The Sylvia was recommended to us by a friend local to Vancouver who said that it was a charming, locally owned hotel in a great location. The location was truly lovely, but although the hotel staff were competent and friendly, the hotel itself was sadly lacking in every respect. The elevators are horribly small and outdated. The carpets are dirty, worn and buckling. The third floor corridor baseboards had holes in the plaster work, and the smell was truly odd. The room was clean enough, but very dimly lit and the acoustical tile on the ceiling was not what I would call charming. The bathroom was the only bright spot - teeny tiny (TRULY) but at least cute in its way. The furniture was worn and the mattresses were hard. The paint scheme was even bland. I truly wanted to like this place, but honestly, couldn't find much to like. What a disappointment...can't figure out what rooms all the folks who wrote glowing reviews stayed in, because ours was awful, as were the common areas. Oh, and the breakfast food at the restaurant wasn't very good...all around, I'd say to avoid this place unless you don't have another choice in the area.

Reviews.Title: “What Hotel Sylvia Did These Other Reviewers Stay At?”
Reviews.Author: Pavla
Reviews.Content: Upon arriving home from our weekend in Vancouver, I had to reread the "glowing" TripAdvisor reviews that caused us to book a room at the Sylvia. Just as I'd remembered, many, many visitors gushed over this hotel as though it was not to be missed. I guess we just got "lucky" and were given the worst hotel room in modern history...all for the price of $180 per wretched night. And what kind of hotel rooms do all of these reviewers normally stay in...it scares me to wonder what they'd consider unsuitable. Where to begin...oh yes...the elevators were not working for most of our stay...neither one of the 2 tiny slow groaning machines worked, making our room a virtual sixth floor walkup. I would have thought that an unusual situation but a Vancouver friend informed me it happens all the time but it has never been properly fixed for very long. Some have called this place "quaint"...hardly...it is dilapidated, worn, old-style old world without any of the old world charm...all it has going for it is its location...a huge draw but not enough to compensate for the nightmare...I'd rather walk or take a bus to the beach than pay $$$ for the insult which comes with a stay at the Sylvia. The rooms...hideous dark green hospital toned paint, one glaring bulb on ceiling, 2 shorted out lamps from the late 50's, 2 small bland, faded pictures hung crookededly on wall, a dark brown kitchen, a bath with only one working lightbulb/fixture of approx 40 watts, faded flowered bedspreads...dirty, danish modern chairs from early 60s...stained, no heat in room...extra blankets...dirty...only 2 towels for 3 people and no amount of begging could get us more towels. I showered with a hand towel to dry. And to top it all off...the Hotel Sylvia allows dogs in every room...every room...complete with the things that dogs leave behind...hair, stains, smells and most of all...fleas...yes...and these were very hungry fleas...we all had bites all over our ankles and awoke in the middle of the night to find fleas in bed with us...hopping on the white sheets under our glaring light bulb...but did the people at the desk care...? Nope...not one "bit" (excuse the pun), as they explained "the hotel allows pets in all rooms..." as though that excuses the Hotel from ridding the premises of fleas. Location, Location, Location...but ask yourself...is it really worth it? Our family says NO!!!

Reviews.Title: “Highly Recommended!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Sylvia for three nights in August. We found it to be extremely charming and reasonably priced ($95 CAN). The staff was quite friendly and helpful. The room was somewhat small but immaculate. Internet is available to guests in the lobby (beware of a long wait since it is free of charge). As others have mentioned, the hotel is very close to Stanley Park as well as the numerous restaurants in the area - guests cannot ask for a better location.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, lovely hotel, wonderful service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Can't say enough about the lovely Sylvia Hotel in Vancouver. Its location was perfect, adjacent to Sunset Beach and very close to Stanley Park. Getting around by bus was a snap, and there were dozens of interesting restaurants within an easy walk. The service at the Sylvia was first rate, from inexpensive room service fare to helpful pointers from the desk staff. Our room was inexpensive, but its size was acceptable and the appointments were tasteful if a little dated. The room and its bath were always spotless thanks to the friendly staff. Our lone complaint was that we heard a lot of neighborhood noise. We were on the second floor and the noise of garbage trucks and good-natured neighborhood revelers was occasionally intrusive. A room above the third floor would be unlikely to have this problem. Very highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect location next to Stanley Park”
Reviews.Author: needdm
Reviews.Content: My family stayed at the hotel for three nights between July 16th and July 18th, and thought the Slyvia was great. We would definitely stay there again. It's major asset is it's location on English Bay, and a block away from Stanley Park. It is also reasonably close to downtown, which is walkable in about 30 minutes, or alternatively catch the bus, we used the number 5 which went up Denman Street and then down Robson. If you use the bus worth buying the day rover ticket. We used it to to Grouse Mountain and back. Rooms are big. We are a family of three, and had a Queen bed in one room, with a separate single bed in the other. The furnishings are not modern, but that is part of the appeal of this hotel. There also was no coffee making facilties in the room. although if you stay in a suite you will have full kitchen facilitiies. The restaurant at the hotel was very good value, and has wonderful views across English bay. If you do not want to eat in the hotel, there are plenty of alternatives on Denham and Davie Street. The staff were very helpful throughout our stay. Only problem we had was with the service at Breakfast on our second day when they were short staffed. Waited half hour for our order to be taken, and ended up walking out and going elsewhere. On the other two days the service was fine, and the breakfast wonderful.

Reviews.Title: “stayed there with my 3 teenage daughters, we loved it”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: loved the location, we could walk anywhere within the downtown core, go to the seabus, and visit granville Island, enjoyed the big rooms, the downstairs restaurant, a very wonderful place full of character. .. give it a try

Reviews.Title: “Great old Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Right on the beach overlooking English Bay,built in 1913 and still very comfortable at reasonable cost.We had a small bayside suite with bedroom,living room and kitchen which was quite roomy and set up to accomodate us and our visiting grandson.We all loved it and Stanley Park with its wonderful Aquarium was next door plus many varied restaurants and shops in the West End of this remarkable city.We used to live in Vancouver and now live across the Straits of Georgia on Vancouver Island. The restaurant is wonderfully located and the excellent bar is alongside with views of the nighttime activity on the beach and the street. Do not expect ultra modern anything but for solid comfort and pleasant staff in a great location this takes the biscuit.

Reviews.Title: “Location great, everything else... not so much.”
Reviews.Author: margand
Reviews.Content: If you're expecting 4 or 5 star rooms and service you won't find that at the Sylvia. If you want a good value (maybe 2.5 - 3 stars) in a great location then the Sylvia is your place. Admittedly, I probably had one of the least desirable rooms in the hotel; low floor, not facing any view and old furnishings (allegedly, some rooms have been "renovated”). I was really disappointed when I first arrived in the rather dumpy lobby and even more so when I saw the lack of luxury of my room. However, after a five day stay, I grew rather fond of this quirky, nostalgic old place. One night when I was in the lobby, an elderly man was checking in. He enthusiastically told the young desk clerk that he had last stayed at the Sylvia some 51 years ago and lo and behold, “nothing has changed a bit.” Well, that’s probably true. Not much there was shiny or fancy or new but it was comfortable, clean and quiet. With the best parts of Vancouver just outside the doors the Sylvia is a fine value and a valuable find. Note: The only problem I had was that when I checked out on Sunday morning at 5 am, I paid by credit card but was told that I couldn’t get a paper receipt because the “printer was broken.” As I was traveling on business the need for a receipt was not negotiable. The hotel offered to mail me a receipt and they did. Unfortunately, it is little more than a dot-matrix print out of my room charges without even a hotel logo on it… not terribly professional but hopefully enough to get my reimbursement.

Reviews.Title: “What a great place”
Reviews.Author: BBCPDX
Reviews.Content: The Sylvia is becoming like a second home for us. We recently had a suite with a corner bay view - recently renovated. It was lovely. Our kids had their own bedroom, with twin beds, and we took the comfy fold-out couch in the living room. The kitchen was well equipped- even has a cool electric teakettle and working oven/range. The place is cozy, warm and wonderful. The restaurant is great in the morning for gazing out at the bay and enjoying your coffee. The bar looks inviting (tho we didn't get a chance to hang out there this time). It's really hard to find a nice hotel, at a good price, that isn't part of a faceless international chain. The Sylvia harkens back to a simpler, homier time in hotelling. Heartily recommended!

Reviews.Title: “An oldie but goodie!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This was our third trip to Canada but the first time we'd actually managed to get a room in the Sylvia. We'd always left it too late and this very popular hotel was always fully booked. It was well worth the wait though. Although an old fashioned kind of place it was warm and welcoming, and the reception staff were always smiling and helpful. Our rooms were very comfortable and relaxing, especially our second room (we did a round trip and started and finished at the Sylvia) which had a fabulous view of English Bay. Their restaurant was also very good, we loved the wonderful choice of breakfast and dinner, with the bonus of great views across the bay (the sunsets were fantastic) and we had lovely servers who helped to make the meal. We so enjoyed our stay - we can't wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Good value, great location”
Reviews.Author: Ostrich
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Sylvia from 12-16 September 2004. When we first booked, all the reviews and guidebook mentions were excellent. However, later reviews had us worried - had we done the right thing? Well, we decided the Sylvia was good. OK, no air-con, but then they don't claim to have it and if its that important to you, you pick a hotel that does. We had a lovely room on the 5th floor corner. Very light and airy with windows on two sides and overlooking the bay - beautiful. The room was quite old-fashioned but charming and had everything we needed. Its location couldn't be bettered - Stanley Park is beautiful and the walk or bus to downtown was easy. Buses by the way are great and the drivers a fountain of knowledge and very polite and helpful. Staff at the hotel were friendly enough and helpful when we left our cases very early on the first day. The restaurant was ok but we only ate there once as there are lots of places to go. We recommend Bridges on Granville Island and The Fish House in Stanley Park - a real treat! Not cheap but if you eat at 5 or 5.30 there is a 15 dollar discount and no sense of rush so you can take as long as you want. Fish is gorgeous and staff great. Back to the Sylvia - good value, good location and we would go there again.

Reviews.Title: “A true bargain”
Reviews.Author: TorontoView
Reviews.Content: The Sylvia is not a fancy hotel. Expect old furniture and the carpets being a bit threadbare. But it is a true Vancouver institution, and the location cannot be beat. It is an UNBELIEVABLE BARGAIN for where it is situated. I used to live in Vancouver and the downstairs bar was my favorite place in the city. Get a spot by the window, order up a beer and settle in with a book. Paradise. I went a couple of years ago after having been out of town for five years and the bartender even remembered what kind of beer I drank. Amazing. If you are a budget traveller looking for a great place, stay here. If you are picky and snobby don't bother....you won't fit in.

Reviews.Title: “It's not the Ritz”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: If you've scrolled down this far, you know you are not looking at the Ritz. A funny thing happened reading these reviews. We traveled to Vancouver in July 2004. We made our reservations in April 2004, and when I checked this site almost all the reviews said the Sylvia was "...fabulous, charming..." But the reviews that have come in after our trip are more on the mark. When I walked into the Sylvia I thought "This place is a dump! What were those reviewers on TripAdvisor thinking?" Then I saw the room. It was a dump too. I told my wife "When we get back to California I am re-reading those reviews. Maybe I missed something." The reviews I just read that were posted after our trip in July 2004 are really more accurate than the reviews from 2003 or early 2004. The Sylvia has a great location and a low price. You can walk to Stanley Park, the restaurants on Denman Street, Granville Island, and even to Gas Town. Walking on the beach at sunset, across from the Sylvia, is one my best memories. But the hotel itself -- get real. This place was a dump forty years ago when they bought the cheap furniture and carpets, and they have not been cleaned since. If you want the best location in Vancouver and don't care about anything else, this place is for you. If you want someplace special with romantic memories, keep looking and pay more. BEST RESTAURANT IN VANCOUVER On Denman Street to try the Banana Leaf restaurant. It is one of the best places I have ever eaten.

Reviews.Title: “It's all in the location.”
Reviews.Author: CGAW
Reviews.Content: If it's location you want, you would be hard pushed to find a better one. Located virtually at the entrance to Stanley Park, this hotel is ideally situated. The hotel and room sadly were a bit tired. It has everything you need, it's generally well equiped and I would just about recommend it. However, if you want modern fixtures and a variety of facilities this is not the hotel for you. It was ok. I'm sorry I cannot put it higher than that. We stayed in six hotels in the space of 3 weeks. This was in first place for location, but in 5th or 6th for everything else and was the most expensive. The windows fully open and could present a risk for a family with young children. We were on the sixth floor. Staff were very friendly and courteous. Doubt you'll get the bellhop to smile though. We would not stay here again. Colin.

Reviews.Title: “Location makes it worthwhile”
Reviews.Author: mlzafron
Reviews.Content: The location of the Sylvia can't be beat. We were there for the Fireworks festival and had the best seats in the house. Also, it was very close to a lot of restaurants and Stanley Park. While the room was a good size, the bathroom wasn't. No A/C means open windows in the summer and while it wasn't hot, the noise level outside was high. The elevator wasn't in great shape and kept breaking down. Staff wasn't the friendliest in the world either. I'd stay there again, but only because of the location and the price. This could be a much better hotel if they'd put some money into it. Loved the hotel cat though...

Reviews.Title: “Shameful!”
Reviews.Content: Sadly, my love affair with the Sylvia is over! I have stayed here many times and had a wonderful experience. However, my current trip was a complete disaster. The room we stayed in had ceiling tiles that were not properly affixed and did "the wave" with the window open. As there is no air conditioning, an open window in the summer here is a must. It kept us awake all night! But the worst part was the unsympathethic staff who seemed to suggest that it wasn't a big deal and made no effort to fix the problem. I could go on and on about how poorly we were treated. We were forced to stay one night as the rude clerk refused to bend on the 24 hour notice policy. I will never stay at the Sylvia again after the deplorable treatment we received. P.S. It would be nice if they bought some screens for the windows to keep the bugs out!

Reviews.Title: “location is great, but...”
Reviews.Author: dbhr
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Sylvia Hotel in June, 2004. My teenage daughter liked it a lot because she got a separate room; my husband thought it was okay; and I was disappointed with it having read great reviews. The pros: - A great location near a beach, Stanley Park, restaurants, etc. - Large bedroom, and a separate bedroom for our daughter, for a reasonable price. - Room was ready for early arrival. The sort-of-cons: - No A/C and no fans -- it's HOT when you stay there in the summer. - Windows had no screens, and didn't stay open without being propped up. - No refrigerator or ice bucket in the room. - Glasses left upside-down on sink counter with no sanitary protection. - Rooms are painted dingy colors. - Taxis drop you at front door, where there are stairs to go up with your luggage, and no one came out to help carry luggage in. - Minimal staff, who were polite but not friendly upon our arrival. - Felt like an old apartment on the upper west side of Manhattan, with little modern improvement.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Location and Views”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Sylvia is a beautiful old hotel. The location is excellent - opposite the beach, a short stroll to Stanley Park and restaurants. The staff were friendly and quite helpful. The rooms are nothing fancy, however, are spacious, comfortable and clean. I would be happy to stay here again and feel it is very well priced for the location and views.

Reviews.Title: “5 stars for the Sylvia!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I have just spent 2 weeks in Vancouver staying at the Sylvia and we found it an excellent hotel. The staff are all really friendly, polite and willing to help with anything - they will even stop to chat if they have the time. The rooms are basic, but comfortable, the restaurant and bar offer good food and service with a smile and the views over English Bay are amazing, particularly at sunset. The location of the hotel couldn't be better. Opposite the beach, a short walk to Stanley Park, Denman and Davie streets and a comfortable walking distance to downtown - or catch the bus from one of the many nearby bus stops. If we come to Vancouver again we would stay at the Sylvia in a heartbeat. Vancouver and the surrounding area is beautiful and our stay at the Sylvia was the icing on the cake for a thoroughly enjoyable holiday. 100% recommended! PS: Ask them about the cat!

Reviews.Title: “Spacious”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel is old but the advantage is the rooms are very spacious. The view over English Bay is another plus. Breakfast downstairs in the restaurant and enjoy the scenary.
